data.text: Where to Work with a Laptop on Long-Distance Bike Tours?

Hey a question to people who work online during long-distance tours, and particularly creatives/filmmakers/youtubers. We're just about to leave for a long tour and thinking how best to still produce work along the way. Will be crossing through Europe first and camping then seek some kind of accommodation to work. Not sure how to manage touring with working, battery life, wifi etc. I know perhaps the simplest choice would be to stay in accommodation intermittently but this will be pretty expensive across Europe. I was wondering what others do? Any useful tips for finding cheap accommodation options? Do you work in cafes? Do you take some kind of dongle? Use Warmshowers/work exchange options? Also, would be cool to know any other touring filmmakers :)

No if you want to use Warmshowers. It's about interaction and you need to focus on your work. You cannot say to a host - Hey, I've got work to do. Personally renting a place if need work. Even now looking for one. Might mean going to a cheaper country.
data.author: Ewa Åšwiderska

data.text: I agree with the no to Warmshowers -- I'm guessing you'd want more than one or two nights to stay and work -- we would not host someone for that purpose. You could always be upfront with your requests (IMHO that would be essential), but I'd expect you'll have a low acceptance.
data.author: Julian C. Westerhout

data.text: Yes, for Warm Showers I was more meaning for recharging everything and stuff like emails, not as a workbase. Too much conversation to be had ðŸ˜ƒ
data.author: Joshua Kian

data.text: Europe isn't terribly expensive for accommodation. Especially considering you are working. Airbnb is an option I found to be better priced in Europe than even hostels in the popular cities. Though this was 6 years ago. Coffee shop hopping works for me. Though I try to hop before wearing out my welcome and be a good customer
data.author: Michael Viglianco

data.text: it is for me. Please, it's all subjective, depending on income, and it differs a lot in Europe itself. Not the best advice.
data.author: Ewa Åšwiderska

data.text: I found hostels for 20/night and airbnbs for 60/night, if that's not affordable enough for work then maybe there's a larger problem and bike touring isn't the answer?
data.author: Nick Stephens

data.text: Im sorry but its true. Paying for your office is a part of work/travel life. Occasional budget accommodation in most of Europe is much cheaper than normal rent for many places.
data.author: Michael Viglianco

data.text: It depends where you are coming from. If from north america especially, accommodation options are much more affordable.
data.author: Michael Viglianco

data.text: that's the point. Where you come from and what you do
data.author: Ewa Åšwiderska

data.text: and you can make your route based on budget. For example go to Bosni and Albania instead of Sweden and Switzerland.
data.author: Michael Viglianco

data.text: have you considered other nations than the US and western Europe? You might not know the salaries elsewhere. It's subjective as I said, worth admitting perspective can differ.
data.author: Ewa Åšwiderska

data.text: guess what. That's what I've been doing and even mentioned in my first reply. Guess why don't tour Switzerland or Sweden? I don't need this kind of advice. I go to cheaper countries or do housesitting. Managed for more than 8 years like that. It's not about me but others. I just wanted to point out it's subjective. You are in SEAsia and know their salaries. When I see somebody saying 60 EUR is cheap while the average earning in my country is around 600-700 EUR a month and saying problem is on me than sorry.
data.author: Ewa Åšwiderska

data.text: I earn more than 700 euro a week or month, but I certainly couldn't afford to travel paying â‚¬60/night for very long.
data.author: Adrian Cheung

data.text: they don't need to do it every night and no need to pay 60 euro I'm currently looking at rooms in Prague this Summer for $23 not 6O euro. And they are 2 so that's $12 a person a few nights a week. Cheep as an established campground
data.author: Michael Viglianco

data.text: Rooms in Sarajevo on Agoda for 2 literally as low as $1 a night. Tons in the 5 to 7 range.....for 2 people. Tirana around $10 to $15 per night.
data.author: Michael Viglianco

data.text: yes but accross Europe is not necessarily across the Balkans. No need to discuss it more.
data.author: Ewa Åšwiderska

data.text: , I'm curious. How do you find places that cheap in Prague? Hostel dorm room? Room in a private house? In the past, I often saw people standing in the main train station, offering a cheap room in their house. However, I was not aware of that on my last couple of visits. Also, you have brought up another interesting point: The mention of the price for two people. Generally, the price for one person is as much as for two, so a single person is paying twice as much per night , than a couple ( referring to hotels, motels, some guest houses and camp grounds that have a charge per site,.)
data.author: Biff Frederikson

data.text: , I lived in Switzerland and earned a mid-level salary, but still couldn't afford to stay in hotels there and also never went to Sweden due to the costs! ðŸ˜• I understand exactly what you mean regarding the different perspectives of what "isn't terribly expensive." Even the idea that has been suggested of using a cafe for working at, can be beyond the budget of some people. Here, in NZ I sometimes include a cafe in my daily rides, but if I was to buy one coffee and a scone each day, that would add up to 35 euro a week - that maybe fine for anyone who is only touring for a week, but not for anyone on the long distance bike rides with low, or no income for a long period. Would you mind sharing how you find places to house sit? Do you do it via a website? If so, which one do you recommend? :-)
data.author: Biff Frederikson

data.text: Balkan is cheap and great place for touring and hiking beautiful mountains.ðŸ˜Ž
data.author: TomaÅ¾ Å vagan

data.text: Thank you, feels better not to be an alien. I've been just researching an affordable place for next month and used Airbnb lots do know the market. Also, the cafes are not for everyone- I teach and have to have a separate, silent place. Earning a few hundred EUR a month doesn't give much choice. Housesitting- frankly speaking was lucky. I got my first sit on Italy and return to the same family. Now for nearly... 5 months!Plus some other sits. Do it for friends as well.. I use Mindmyhouse as the cheapest, but you don't find many sits there. Maybe you'd be interested in reasing my post on that, but the automatic translation might suck.
data.author: Ewa Åšwiderska

data.author: Ewa Åšwiderska

data.text: I am trying to help the person who asked the question. I will provide what I know as I see fit
data.author: Michael Viglianco

data.text: Agreed that 'not terribly expensive' is very subjective. For some Europe isn't, it's also arguably the most expensive part of the world to travel...
data.author: Joshua Kian

data.text: I used to have a housesitter at my home here in Colorado while I bike toured through winters in SE Asia or other tours but she passed away (at 42 years old) and I've never been able to find anyone again. My neighbor picks up my mail but I'd love to be able to find a housesitter again for my home when I bike tour 3-4 months. I've never asked the housesitter to pay any utilities either, nor do I have any pets.
data.author: Len DeMoss

data.text:
exactly, that irks the hell out of me when I see hotel rooms (on hotel website or even booking.com) where the price of a room is the same for 1 person as it is for 2 and that's even with free breakfasts. Always makes me want to ask for 2 breakfasts at the hotel if I'm paying same as for 2.
Booking.com: The largest selection of hotels, homes, and vacation rentals
booking.com

data.text: There are many websites that can help you to find a sitter. I even mention some in my post. No idea why you had a problem, sounds like a good deal. For me the US wouldn't work.
data.author: Ewa Åšwiderska

data.text: , lol. I have also been tempted to ask for a second breakfast. Or if is a place that has a buffet breakfast, I feel no guilt at making up a sandwich, taking some fruit and a boiled egg, for my lunch.
data.author: Biff Frederikson

data.text: For battery life, try using a PedalCell dynamo. Have a look online for reviews... imho it won't fully recharge a flat laptop battery, but you'd be surprised what it can do, imho
data.author: Adrian Cheung

data.text: We have one of them! Awesome bit of kit. Works fine for phone, camera and small devices but don't the computer is the issue
data.author: Joshua Kian

data.text:
Look for house sitting opportunities For example: https://housesitsearch.com/location/europe
Find 1000s of House Sitting Jobs in Europe | HouseSitSearch
housesitsearch.com
data.author: Rachel Hugens

data.text: We've intended on doing this for a number of trips and then ended up doing a work exchange instead. Purely cos dates didn't work out. Definitely something for the future. Do you know if this has slowed down much since COVID?
data.author: Joshua Kian

data.text: I'm touring around South western Europe right now and it's incredibly expensive nowadays to find a cheap hostel. A bunk bed in Italy no less than 30 euros (this isn't cheap, no matter how much you get paid). Not to mention France prices. You can book something cheaper if you do it one or two months in advance. But for who decide the route day by day (even by weeks) accommodation is pretty expensive. Of course, you have warmshowers and Cs, but as someone said before, not to arrive and get to your room to work. That wouldn't be fair for me.
data.author: Javier Suero Diaz

data.text: Public libraries and University campuses. Great places work quietly, free electricity and no one trying to move you on. Also check out the public notice boards as they often advertise interesting and cheap/free events. Often a good place to meet interesting and decent local people. I like the smaller less well known museums and galleries as places to hangout if the are free. Also a good places if you want to avoid a rainy day.
data.author: Trevor Piper

data.text: Almost forgot, public swim centers are often cheap for a day pass and make a great place to hangout for a day with access to electricity and other facility with no one hassling you to move on. They also tend to have good secure bike storage facilities.
data.author: Trevor Piper

data.text: Awesome suggestions - thanks. And agreed, students are always good people to meet when you're on the road
data.author: Joshua Kian

data.text: Following. I'm also a filmmaker. When I did bikepacking before I wasn't working. I'd like to plan a trip for the summer and work at the same time.
data.author: Nellie Khossousi

data.text: Nice to meet ya. Interested to know what you'll be doing in terms of file storage. I fill up external hardrives in no time so hoping to find a better alternative...
data.author: Joshua Kian

data.text: @Joshua Kian Nice to meet you too. I have the SanDisk extreme portable harddrive. Very small and light weight. I have thought about cloud storage but don't use one at the moment. Would potentially increase my storage on Google drive.
data.author: Nellie Khossousi
